Description: Head of a calcite figure of a cow: this superbly carved head came from a statue of the goddess Hathor in her animal manifestation. The eyebrows and makeup lines around the eyes were once inlaid with lapis lazuli; there are traces of rock crystal in the eye sockets. The hole in the forehead was for the attachment of a gold sun disc between two precious metal horns.
Curator's comments: Although this piece was found in debris on the platform of the 11th Dynasty temple at Deir el-Bahri, undoubtedly, it originally came from the sanctuary of the 18th Dynasty shrine to the goddess built high above, at the southern end of the second terrace of Queen Hatshepsut's temple. Life-sized cult statues of Hathor as a cow depict her protecting the king himself between her forelegs and giving him milk straight from the udder. Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), 76-77 No 15; B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' II (2) (Oxford, 1974), p.394. G. Pinch, Votive offerings to Hathor (Oxford 1993), p.5, pl.9 (centre).
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.60-61)
Exhibition history: Echibited; 1977 London, BM, Animals in Art
